analyzed: duryodhano karot vairam pāṇḍu putraiḥ mahā balaiḥ  sa katham rathinām śreṣṭhaḥ karṇaḥ pārthena saṃyuge

translated: He was appointed by brave, capable and powerful kings

analyzed: tam śrutvā nihatam karṇam dvairathe savyasācinā
translated: Hearing that Karna was killed in a chariot duel by Savyasachi,

analyzed: nṛvṛṣam nihatam śrutvā dvairathe rathinām varam  śoka arṇave nimagnaḥ ham aplavaḥ sāgare yathā

analyzed: īdṛśaiḥ yadi aham duḥkhaiḥ na vinaśyāmi saṃjaya

analyzed: jñāti saṃbandhi mitrāṇām imam śrutvā parājayam
translated: Having heard about the defeat of my relatives, kinsmen and friends,

analyzed: kaḥ mat anyaḥ pumān loke na jahyāt sūta jīvitam  viṣam agnim prapātam vā parvata agrāt aham vṛṇe

analyzed: mahāprasthāna gamanam jalam prāya upaveśanam
translated: I will go on the great journey, enter the water, or sit down to fast.

original: na hi śakṣyāmi duḥkhāni soḍhuṃ kaṣṭāni saṃjaya
analyzed: na hi śakṣyāmi duḥkhāni soḍhum kaṣṭāni saṃjaya

original: cintayann eva sīdāmi mano me 'tīva muhyati
analyzed: cintayan eva sīdāmi manaḥ me tīva muhyati
translated: Thinking about it, I am sinking; my mind is extremely confused.

original: saṃjaya uvāca🔽śriyā kulena yaśasā tapasā ca śrutena ca
analyzed: saṃjayaḥ uvāca  śriyā kulena yaśasā tapasā ca śrutena ca

analyzed: tvām adya santaḥ manyante yayātim iva nāhuṣam
translated: You are considered by the virtuous today to be like Yayati, the son of Nahusha, in glory, lineage, fame, austerity and learning.

analyzed: śrute mahā ṛṣi pratimaḥ kṛtakṛtyaḥ si pārthiva
translated: O king, you have accomplished your purpose, you are like a great sage in learning.

analyzed: paryavasthāpaya ātmānam mā viṣāde manaḥ kṛthāḥ
translated: Control yourself, do not set your mind on sorrow.

analyzed: dhṛtarāṣṭraḥ uvāca
translated: Dhritarashtra said:

original: daivam eva paraṃ manye dhik pauruṣam anarthakam
analyzed: daivam eva param manye dhik pauruṣam anarthakam
translated: I consider destiny to be supreme, fie on purposeless manliness,

analyzed: yatra rāma pratīkāśaḥ karṇaḥ hanyata saṃyuge
translated: where Karna, who was like Rama, was killed in battle,

analyzed: hatvā yudhiṣṭhira anīkam pāñcālānām ratha vrajān
translated: having destroyed Yudhishthira's army and the hordes of Panchala chariots,

analyzed: pratāpya śara varṣeṇa diśaḥ sarvāḥ mahā rathaḥ
translated: the great warrior who scorched all directions with his shower of arrows,

analyzed: mohayitvā raṇe pārthān vajrahastaḥ iva asurān
translated: Having confounded the Parthas in battle, like the wielder of the thunderbolt the asuras,

original: sa kathaṃ nihataḥ śete vātarugṇa iva drumaḥ
analyzed: sa katham nihataḥ śete vāta rugṇaḥ iva drumaḥ
translated: How is it that he lies slain, like a tree struck down by the wind?

analyzed: śokasya antam na paśyāmi samudrasya iva viplukāḥ
translated: I do not see an end to my grief, like the waves of the ocean.

original: cintā me vardhate tīvrā mumūrṣā cāpi jāyate
analyzed: cintā me vardhate tīvrā mumūrṣā ca api jāyate
translated: My anxiety increases intensely, and a desire to die arises in me.

original: karṇasya nidhanaṃ śrutvā vijayaṃ phalgunasya ca
analyzed: karṇasya nidhanam śrutvā vijayam phalgunasya ca
translated: Having heard of the death of Karna and the victory of Phalguna,

original: aśraddheyam ahaṃ manye vadhaṃ karṇasya saṃjaya
analyzed: aśraddheyam aham manye vadham karṇasya saṃjaya
translated: I consider the death of Karna to be unbelievable, O Sanjaya.

analyzed: vajra sāra mayam nūnam hṛdayam su dṛḍham mama
translated: Surely my heart is made of the essence of the thunderbolt, and is very firm,

original: yac chrutvā puruṣavyāghraṃ hataṃ karṇaṃ na dīryate
analyzed: yat śrutvā puruṣa vyāghram hatam karṇam na dīryate
translated: Since, having heard that Karna, the tiger among men, has been killed, it does not break apart.

original: āyur nūnaṃ sudīrghaṃ me vihitaṃ daivataiḥ purā
analyzed: āyuḥ nūnam su dīrgham me vihitam daivataiḥ purā
translated: Surely my life has been ordained by the gods to be very long,

original: yatra karṇaṃ hataṃ śrutvā jīvāmīha suduḥkhitaḥ
analyzed: yatra karṇam hatam śrutvā jīvāmi iha su duḥkhitaḥ
translated: Since, having heard that Karna has been killed, I still live here, extremely miserable.

original: dhig jīvitam idaṃ me 'dya suhṛd dhīnasya saṃjaya
analyzed: dhik jīvitam idam me suhṛd hīnasya saṃjaya
translated: Shame on this life of mine today, O Sanjaya, bereft of friends.

original: adya cāhaṃ daśām etāṃ gataḥ saṃjaya garhitām
analyzed: adya ca aham daśām etām gataḥ saṃjaya garhitām
translated: And today I have attained this despicable state, O Sanjaya,

analyzed: kṛpaṇam vartayiṣyāmi śocyaḥ sarvasya manda dhīḥ
translated: I shall live a wretched life, to be pitied by all, slow-witted as I am.

original: aham eva purā bhūtvā sarvalokasya satkṛtaḥ
analyzed: aham eva purā bhūtvā sarva lokasya satkṛtaḥ
translated: Having been honored by all the world in the past,

original: paribhūtaḥ kathaṃ sūta punaḥ śakṣyāmi jīvitum
analyzed: paribhūtaḥ katham sūta punar śakṣyāmi jīvitum
translated: How shall I be able to live again, O charioteer, being despised?

original: duḥkhāt suduḥkhaṃ vyasanaṃ prāptavān asmi saṃjaya
analyzed: duḥkhāt su duḥkham vyasanam prāptavān asmi saṃjaya
translated: I have fallen from sorrow into greater sorrow, O Sanjaya.

original: tasmād bhīṣmavadhe caiva droṇasya ca mahātmanaḥ
analyzed: tasmāt bhīṣma vadhe ca eva droṇasya ca mahātmanaḥ
translated: Therefore, in the slaying of Bhishma and the great-souled Drona,

original: nātra śeṣaṃ prapaśyāmi sūtaputre hate yudhi
analyzed: na atra śeṣam prapaśyāmi sūtaputre hate yudhi
translated: I see no remainder, O charioteer, when the son of Suta is slain in battle.

original: sa hi pāraṃ mahān āsīt putrāṇāṃ mama saṃjaya
analyzed: sa hi pāram mahān āsīt putrāṇām mama saṃjaya
translated: For he was a great support to my sons, O Sanjaya,

original: yuddhe vinihataḥ śūro visṛjan sāyakān bahūn
analyzed: yuddhe vinihataḥ śūraḥ visṛjan sāyakān bahūn
translated: the hero who was slain in battle, shooting many arrows.

original: ko hi me jīvitenārthas tam ṛte puruṣarṣabham
analyzed: kaḥ hi me jīvitena arthaḥ tam ṛte puruṣa ṛṣabham
translated: What purpose does life serve to me without that bull among men?

analyzed: rathāt atirathaḥ nūnam apatat sāyaka arditaḥ
translated: Surely the Atiratha fell from his chariot, afflicted by arrows,

analyzed: parvatasya iva śikharam vajra pāta vidāritam
translated: like the peak of a mountain shattered by a thunderbolt.

analyzed: śayīta pṛthivīm nūnam śobhayan rudhira ukṣitaḥ
translated: He must be lying on the ground, beautifying it with his blood,

analyzed: mātaṅgaḥ iva mattena mātaṅgena nipātitaḥ
translated: like an elephant fallen by another maddened elephant.

original: yad balaṃ dhārtarāṣṭrāṇāṃ pāṇḍavānāṃ yato bhayam
analyzed: yat balam dhārtarāṣṭrāṇām pāṇḍavānām yatas bhayam
translated: That was the strength of the sons of Dhritarashtra, from which the Pandavas were afraid.

analyzed: saḥ rjunena hataḥ karṇaḥ pratimānam dhanuṣmatām
translated: That Karna, the measure of archers, has been killed by Arjuna.

original: sa hi vīro maheṣvāsaḥ putrāṇām abhayaṃkaraḥ
analyzed: sa hi vīraḥ mahā iṣvāsaḥ putrāṇām abhayaṃkaraḥ
translated: That hero, a great archer, the protector of my sons from fear,

original: śete vinihato vīraḥ śakreṇeva yathā balaḥ
analyzed: śete vinihataḥ vīraḥ śakreṇa iva yathā balaḥ
translated: lies slain, the hero, like Bala by Shakra.

analyzed: paṅgoḥ iva adhva gamanam daridrasya iva kāmitam
translated: Like the journey of a cripple, like the desire of a poor man,

analyzed: duryodhanasya cākūtam tṛṣitasya iva piplukāḥ
translated: Like moths to a flame, they have fallen into the designs of Duryodhana, as if he were Death himself.

original: anyathā cintitaṃ kāryam anyathā tat tu jāyate
analyzed: anyathā cintitam kāryam anyathā tat tu jāyate
translated: What is thought to be one way turns out to be another.

original: aho nu balavad daivaṃ kālaś ca duratikramaḥ
analyzed: aho nu balavat daivam kālaḥ ca duratikramaḥ
translated: Alas! Destiny is powerful and time is difficult to overcome.

analyzed: palāyamānaḥ kṛpaṇam dīna ātmā dīna pauruṣaḥ
translated: He who fled pitifully, with a wretched soul and poor manliness,

original: kaccin na nihataḥ sūta putro duḥśāsano mama
analyzed: kaccit na nihataḥ sūta putraḥ duḥśāsanaḥ mama
translated: O charioteer, was my son Duhshasana killed?

original: kaccin na nīcācaritaṃ kṛtavāṃs tāta saṃyuge
analyzed: kaccit na nīca ācaritam kṛtavān tāta saṃyuge
translated: O father, did he do anything base in battle?

original: putro duryodhanaḥ saṃkhye nihato mama saṃjaya
analyzed: putraḥ duryodhanaḥ saṃkhye nihataḥ mama saṃjaya
translated: My son Duryodhana was killed in battle, O Sanjaya.

original: kaccin na nihataḥ śūro yathā na kṣatriyā hatāḥ
analyzed: kaccit na nihataḥ śūraḥ yathā na kṣatriyāḥ hatāḥ
translated: Was the hero killed, or were the Kshatriyas not killed in a base way?

analyzed: vaiśaṃpāyanaḥ uvāca
translated: Vaishampayana said:

original: ity evaṃ dhṛtarāṣṭro 'tha vilapya bahu duḥkhitaḥ
analyzed: iti evam vilapya bahu duḥkhitaḥ
translated: Thus Dhritarashtra lamented, greatly afflicted with grief,

analyzed: provāca saṃjayam bhūyas śoka vyākula locanaḥ
translated: and again spoke to Sanjaya, his eyes agitated with sorrow:

analyzed: yaḥ jayat sa varka ambojān ambaṣṭhān kekayaiḥ saha
translated: He who conquered the Karushas, Kambojas, Ambashthas, and Kekayas together,

original: gāndhārāṃś ca videhāṃś ca jitvā kāryārtham āhave🔽yudhiṣṭhirasya vacanaṃ mā yuddham iti sarvadā
analyzed: gāndhārān ca videhān ca jitvā kārya artham āhave  yudhiṣṭhirasya vacanam mā yuddham iti sarvadā
translated: and the Gandharas and Videhas after conquering them in battle for the sake of his duty,

analyzed: duryodhanaḥ na abhyagṛhṇāt mūḍhaḥ pathyam iva auṣadham
translated: Yudhishthira's words, 'Do not fight,' were always disregarded by the foolish Duryodhana, as if they were salutary medicine.

analyzed: śara talpe śayānena bhīṣmeṇa su mahātmanā
translated: While lying on a bed of arrows, by the great-souled Bhishma,

analyzed: pānīyam yācitaḥ pārthaḥ saḥ vidhyat medinī talam
translated: Partha, when asked for water, pierced the surface of the earth.

original: jalasya dhārāṃ vihitāṃ dṛṣṭvā tāṃ pāṇḍavena ha
analyzed: jalasya dhārām vihitām dṛṣṭvā tām pāṇḍavena ha
translated: Seeing that stream of water created by the Pandava,

original: abravīt sa mahābāhus tāta saṃśāmya pāṇḍavaiḥ
analyzed: abravīt sa mahā bāhuḥ tāta saṃśāmya pāṇḍavaiḥ
translated: The mighty-armed one said, O son, make peace with the Pandavas.

original: praśamād dhi bhavec chāntir madantaṃ yuddham astu ca
analyzed: praśamāt hi bhavet śāntiḥ mad antam yuddham astu ca
translated: For peace can bring about tranquility, let the war end with my death.

analyzed: bhrātṛ bhāvena pṛthivīm bhuṅkṣva pāṇḍu sutaiḥ saha
translated: Enjoy the earth as a brother with the sons of Pandu.

original: akurvan vacanaṃ tasya nūnaṃ śocati me sutaḥ
analyzed: akurvan vacanam tasya nūnam śocati me sutaḥ
translated: But my son, not acting on his words, surely grieves.

analyzed: tat idam samanuprāptam vacanam dīrghadarśinaḥ
translated: That statement of the far-sighted one has now come to pass.

original: ahaṃ tu nihatāmātyo hataputraś ca saṃjaya
analyzed: aham tu nihata amātyaḥ hata putraḥ ca saṃjaya
translated: But I, O Sanjaya, am one whose ministers are slain and whose sons are dead,

original: dyūtataḥ kṛcchram āpanno lūnapakṣa iva dvijaḥ
analyzed: dyūtataḥ kṛcchram āpannaḥ lūna pakṣaḥ iva dvijaḥ
translated: Having come to misfortune through gambling, like a bird with clipped wings.

original: yathā hi śakuniṃ gṛhya chittvā pakṣau ca saṃjaya
analyzed: yathā hi śakunim gṛhya chittvā pakṣau ca saṃjaya
translated: Just as, O Sanjaya, having caught a bird and clipped its wings,

analyzed: visarjayanti saṃhṛṣṭāḥ krīḍamānāḥ kumārakāḥ
translated: The joyous young boys let it go, playing around,

analyzed: chinnapakṣa tayā tasya gamanam na upapadyate
translated: Because with its wings cut off, it cannot fly away,

original: tathāham api saṃprāpto lūnapakṣa iva dvijaḥ
analyzed: tathā aham api saṃprāptaḥ lūna pakṣaḥ iva dvijaḥ
translated: In the same way, I have become like a bird with clipped wings.

analyzed: kṣīṇaḥ sarva artha hīnaḥ ca nirbandhuḥ jñāti varjitaḥ
translated: Depleted, devoid of all purpose, without kinsmen, bereft of relatives,

original: kāṃ diśaṃ pratipatsyāmi dīnaḥ śatruvaśaṃ gataḥ
analyzed: kām diśam pratipatsyāmi dīnaḥ śatru vaśam gataḥ
translated: Depressed, under the control of the enemy, to which direction shall I go?

analyzed: duryodhanasya vṛddhi artham pṛthivīm yaḥ jayat prabhuḥ
translated: For the sake of Duryodhana's prosperity, the lord who conquered the earth,

original: sa jitaḥ pāṇḍavaiḥ śūraiḥ samarthair vīryaśālibhiḥ
analyzed: sa jitaḥ pāṇḍavaiḥ śūraiḥ samarthaiḥ vīrya śālibhiḥ
translated: He was defeated by the powerful and valiant Pāṇḍavas.

original: tasmin hate maheṣvāse karṇe yudhi kirīṭinā
analyzed: tasmin hate mahā iṣvāse karṇe yudhi kirīṭinā
translated: When that great archer Karṇa was killed in battle by Kṛṣṇa,

original: ke vīrāḥ paryavartanta tan mamācakṣva saṃjaya
analyzed: ke vīrāḥ paryavartanta tat mama ācakṣva saṃjaya
translated: Which heroes surrounded him? Tell me that, O Sanjaya.

original: kaccin naikaḥ parityaktaḥ pāṇḍavair nihato raṇe
analyzed: kaccit na ekaḥ parityaktaḥ pāṇḍavaiḥ nihataḥ raṇe
translated: Was he not abandoned and killed in battle by the Pāṇḍavas?

original: uktaṃ tvayā purā vīra yathā vīrā nipātitāḥ
analyzed: uktam tvayā purā vīra yathā vīrāḥ nipātitāḥ
translated: You have said before how the heroes were brought down.

analyzed: bhīṣmam a pratiyudhyantam śikhaṇḍī sāyaka uttamaiḥ
translated: Bhīṣma, who was fighting without a rival, was brought down in battle by Śikhaṇḍī with excellent arrows,

analyzed: pātayām āsa samare sarva śastrabhṛtām varam
translated: The best among all wielders of weapons.

analyzed: tathā draupadinā droṇaḥ nyasta sarva āyudhaḥ yudhi
translated: Similarly, Drona, who had laid aside all weapons in battle,🔽Was killed by Drupada's son, O Sanjaya.

original: dharmarājavacaḥ śrutvā aśvatthāmā hatas tv iti
analyzed: dharmarāja vacaḥ śrutvā aśvatthāmā hataḥ tu iti
translated: Having heard the words of Yudhiṣṭhira, that Aśvatthāmā had been killed,

analyzed: yukta yogaḥ mahā iṣvāsaḥ śaraiḥ bahubhiḥ ācitaḥ
translated: The great archer, covered with many arrows,

analyzed: nihataḥ khaḍgam udyamya dhṛṣṭadyumnena saṃjaya
translated: Was killed by Dhṛṣṭadyumna, raising his sword, O Sanjaya.

original: antareṇa hatāv etau chalena ca viśeṣataḥ
analyzed: antareṇa hatau etau chalena ca viśeṣataḥ
translated: These two were killed in between, especially through deceit.

original: aśrauṣam aham etad vai bhīṣmadroṇau nipātitau
analyzed: aśrauṣam aham etat vai bhīṣma droṇau nipātitau
translated: I heard that Bhīṣma and Droṇa were brought down.

original: bhīṣmadroṇau hi samare na hanyād vajrabhṛt svayam
analyzed: bhīṣma droṇau hi samare na hanyāt vajrabhṛt svayam
translated: For Bhīṣma and Droṇa could not be killed in battle even by the wielder of the thunderbolt himself.

original: nyāyena yudhyamānau hi tad vai satyaṃ bravīmi te
analyzed: nyāyena yudhyamānau hi tat vai satyam bravīmi te
translated: I tell you this truthfully.

original: karṇaṃ tv asyantam astrāṇi divyāni ca bahūni ca
analyzed: karṇam tu asyantam astrāṇi divyāni ca bahūni ca
translated: But Karna, who shot many divine weapons,

original: katham indropamaṃ vīraṃ mṛtyur yuddhe samaspṛśat🔽yasya vidyutprabhāṃ śaktiṃ divyāṃ kanakabhūṣaṇām
analyzed: katham indra upamam vīram mṛtyuḥ yuddhe samaspṛśat  yasya vidyut prabhām śaktim divyām kanaka bhūṣaṇām
translated: how did Death touch that hero who was like Indra in battle?🔽To whom Purandara gave the divine spear, which had the luster of lightning and was adorned with gold,

analyzed: prāyacchat dviṣatām hantrīm kuṇḍalābhyām puraṃdaraḥ
translated: which destroyed enemies, in exchange for his earrings;

analyzed: yasya sarpa mukhaḥ divyaḥ śaraḥ kanaka bhūṣaṇaḥ
translated: To whom the divine arrow with a snake head, which was adorned with gold,

analyzed: aśeta nihataḥ patrī candaneṣu ari sūdanaḥ
translated: lay slain, with its feathers, on sandalwood paste, that destroyer of enemies;

analyzed: bhīṣma droṇa mukhān vīrān yaḥ vamanya mahā rathān
translated: Who, disregarding the great warriors headed by Bhishma and Drona,

analyzed: jāmadagnyāt mahā ghoram brāhmam astram aśikṣata
translated: learned the extremely terrible Brahma weapon from Jamadagni's son;

original: yaś ca droṇamukhān dṛṣṭvā vimukhān arditāñ śaraiḥ
analyzed: yaḥ ca droṇa mukhān dṛṣṭvā vimukhān arditām śaraiḥ
translated: And who, seeing Drona and the others turned away, afflicted by arrows,

original: saubhadrasya mahābāhur vyadhamat kārmukaṃ śaraiḥ🔽yaś ca nāgāyutaprāṇaṃ vātaraṃhasam acyutam
analyzed: saubhadrasya mahā bāhuḥ vyadhamat kārmukam śaraiḥ  yaḥ ca nāga ayuta prāṇam vāta raṃhasam acyutam
translated: cut down the great bow of Subhadra's son with arrows;🔽Who, having made his brother Bhimasena, who had the strength of ten thousand elephants and the speed of the wind,

analyzed: viratham bhrātaram kṛtvā bhīmasenam upāhasat
translated: carless, laughed at him;

analyzed: sahadevam ca nirjitya śaraiḥ saṃnata parvabhiḥ
translated: And who, having defeated Sahadeva with straight-tufted arrows,

analyzed: kṛpayā viratham kṛtvā na ahanat dharma vittayā
translated: Out of compassion, he deprived him of his chariot, but did not strike him, knowing the rules of dharma.

analyzed: yaḥ ca māyā sahasrāṇi dhvaṃsayitvā raṇa utkaṭam
translated: And he who destroyed thousands of illusions and defeated the proud

analyzed: ghaṭotkacam rākṣasa indram śakra śaktyā abhijaghnivān
translated: Ghatotkacha, the lord of the rakshasas, with Shakra's spear,

original: etāni divasāny asya yuddhe bhīto dhanaṃjayaḥ
analyzed: etāni divasāni asya yuddhe bhītaḥ dhanaṃjayaḥ
translated: For these days, Dhananjaya, afraid in battle,

original: nāgamad dvairathaṃ vīraḥ sa kathaṃ nihato raṇe
analyzed: na agamat dvairatham vīraḥ sa katham nihataḥ raṇe
translated: Did not come to a duel with the hero. How was he killed in battle?

analyzed: saṃśaptakānām yodhāḥ ye āhvayanta sadā anyatas
translated: The warriors of the samshaptakas, who always challenged others,

original: etān hatvā haniṣyāmi paścād vaikartanaṃ raṇe
analyzed: etān hatvā haniṣyāmi paścāt vaikartanam raṇe
translated: Having killed them, I will kill Vaikartana in battle later.

original: iti vyapadiśan pārtho varjayan sūtajaṃ raṇe
analyzed: iti vyapadiśan pārthaḥ varjayan sūtajam raṇe
translated: Thus speaking, Partha avoided the son of the charioteer in battle.

original: sa kathaṃ nihato vīraḥ pārthena paramāhave
analyzed: sa katham nihataḥ vīraḥ pārthena parama āhave
translated: How was that hero killed by Partha in the great battle?

original: rathasaṅgo na cet tasya dhanur vā na vyaśīryata
analyzed: ratha saṅgaḥ na ced tasya dhanuḥ vā na vyaśīryata
translated: If his chariot was not entangled and his bow was not shattered,

original: na ced astrāṇi nirṇeśuḥ sa kathaṃ nihataḥ paraiḥ
analyzed: na ced astrāṇi nirṇeśuḥ sa katham nihataḥ paraiḥ
translated: And if his weapons did not fail, how was he killed by the enemy?

original: ko hi śakto raṇe karṇaṃ vidhunvānaṃ mahad dhanuḥ
analyzed: kaḥ hi śaktaḥ raṇe karṇam vidhunvānam mahat dhanuḥ
translated: For who is able to defeat Karna in battle, who wields a great bow

original: vimuñcantaṃ śarān ghorān divyāny astrāṇi cāhave
analyzed: vimuñcantam śarān ghorān divyāni astrāṇi ca āhave
translated: And releases terrible arrows and divine weapons in the fight,

analyzed: jetum puruṣa śārdūlam śārdūlam iva vegitam
translated: That tiger among men, who is as swift as a tiger?🔽Surely his bow was cut or his chariot went to the ground,

original: dhruvaṃ tasya dhanuś chinnaṃ ratho vāpi gato mahīm
analyzed: dhruvam tasya dhanuḥ chinnam rathaḥ vā api gataḥ mahīm
translated: Or his weapons were destroyed or he was killed by the enemy.

original: astrāṇi vā pranaṣṭāni yathā śaṃsasi me hatam
analyzed: astrāṇi vā pranaṣṭāni yathā śaṃsasi me hatam
translated: Or if you say that the weapons have been destroyed, as you report the death of Abhimanyu,

original: na hy anyad anupaśyāmi kāraṇaṃ tasya nāśane
analyzed: na hi anyat anupaśyāmi kāraṇam tasya nāśane
translated: I see no other cause for his destruction.

original: na hanyām arjunaṃ yāvat tāvat pādau na dhāvaye
analyzed: na hanyām arjunam yāvat tāvat pādau na dhāvaye
translated: As long as I do not kill Arjuna, I will not wash my feet.

original: iti yasya mahāghoraṃ vratam āsīn mahātmanaḥ
analyzed: iti yasya mahā ghoram vratam āsīt mahātmanaḥ
translated: Such was the terrible vow of that great-souled one.

original: yasya bhīto vane nityaṃ dharmarājo yudhiṣṭhiraḥ
analyzed: yasya bhītaḥ vane nityam dharmarājaḥ yudhiṣṭhiraḥ
translated: Frightened of whom, Dharma King Yudhishthira always remained in the forest,

original: trayodaśa samā nidrāṃ na lebhe puruṣarṣabhaḥ
analyzed: trayodaśa samāḥ nidrām na lebhe puruṣa ṛṣabhaḥ
translated: The best of men did not get sleep for thirteen years.

analyzed: yasya vīryavataḥ vīryam samāśritya mahātmanaḥ
translated: Relying on the valor of that valiant and great-souled one,

original: mama putraḥ sabhāṃ bhāryāṃ pāṇḍūnāṃ nītavān balāt
analyzed: mama putraḥ sabhām bhāryām pāṇḍūnām nītavān balāt
translated: My son forcibly brought the wife of the Pandavas to the assembly hall.

original: tatra cāpi sabhāmadhye pāṇḍavānāṃ ca paśyatām
analyzed: tatra ca api sabhā madhye pāṇḍavānām ca paśyatām
translated: And even there, in the middle of the assembly hall, in the presence of the Pandavas,

analyzed: dāsa bhāryā iti pāñcālīm abravīt kuru saṃsadi
translated: In the Kuru assembly, he called Panchali Krishna a slave's wife.

original: na santi patayaḥ kṛṣṇe sarve ṣaṇḍhatilaiḥ samāḥ
analyzed: na santi patayaḥ kṛṣṇe sarve ṣaṇḍhatilaiḥ samāḥ
translated: O Krishna, your husbands are all like barren sesame seeds.

analyzed: upatiṣṭhasva bhartāram anyam vā varavarṇini
translated: O beautiful one, serve another husband.

original: ity evaṃ yaḥ purā vāco rūkṣāḥ saṃśrāvayan ruṣā
analyzed: iti evam yaḥ purā vācaḥ rūkṣāḥ saṃśrāvayan ruṣā
translated: Thus, in the past, the son of a suta, speaking such harsh words out of anger,

original: sabhāyāṃ sūtajaḥ kṛṣṇāṃ sa kathaṃ nihataḥ paraiḥ
analyzed: sabhāyām sūtajaḥ kṛṣṇām sa katham nihataḥ paraiḥ
translated: How was he killed by the enemy?

original: yadi bhīṣmo raṇaślāghī droṇo vā yudhi durmadaḥ
analyzed: yadi bhīṣmaḥ raṇa ślāghī droṇaḥ vā yudhi durmadaḥ
translated: If Bhishma, who prides himself in battle, or Drona, who is invincible in war,

analyzed: na haniṣyati kaunteyān pakṣapātāt suyodhana
translated: Out of partiality, he will not kill the sons of Kunti, O Suyodhana.

original: sarvān eva haniṣyāmi vyetu te mānaso jvaraḥ
analyzed: sarvān eva haniṣyāmi vyetu te mānasaḥ jvaraḥ
translated: I will kill all of them. Let the fever in your mind be dispelled.

original: kiṃ kariṣyati gāṇḍīvam akṣayyau ca maheṣudhī
analyzed: kim kariṣyati gāṇḍīvam akṣayyau ca mahā iṣudhī
translated: What will the Gandiva bow do, or the two inexhaustible quivers?

analyzed: snigdha candana digdhasya mad śarasya abhidhāvataḥ
translated: When my arrow, smeared with fragrant sandalwood, rushes towards him.

original: sa nūnam ṛṣabhaskandho hy arjunena kathaṃ hataḥ
analyzed: sa nūnam ṛṣabha skandhaḥ hi arjunena katham hataḥ
translated: How was he, whose shoulders were like those of a bull, killed by Arjuna?

original: yaś ca gāṇḍīvamuktānāṃ sparśam ugram acintayan
analyzed: yaḥ ca gāṇḍīva muktānām sparśam ugram a cintayan
translated: He who did not think of the terrible touch of arrows released from the Gandiva,

original: apatir hy asi kṛṣṇeti bruvan pārthān avaikṣata
analyzed: a patiḥ hi asi kṛṣṇā iti bruvan pārthān avaikṣata
translated: And who looked at the Parthas, saying, O Krishna, you are without a husband.

translated: Having heard this from the son of the preceptor, O king, your son

translated: Having performed various paths, circles, and positions,🔽They struck each other with arrows released from fully drawn bows.

original: anyonyasya vadhe yatnaṃ cakratus tau mahārathau
analyzed: anyonyasya vadhe yatnam cakratuḥ tau mahā rathau
translated: Those two great warriors made efforts to kill each other,

original: īṣatur virathaṃ caiva kartum anyonyam āhave
analyzed: īṣatuḥ viratham ca eva kartum anyonyam āhave
translated: And they both tried to make the other chariotless in that battle.

analyzed: tatas drauṇiḥ mahā astrāṇi prāduścakre mahā rathaḥ
translated: Then the great chariot Drona's son displayed great weapons.

original: tāny astrair eva samare pratijaghne 'sya pāṇḍavaḥ
analyzed: tāni astraiḥ eva samare pratijaghne sya pāṇḍavaḥ
translated: The Pandava countered them with his own weapons in that battle.

analyzed: tatas ghoram mahā rāja astra yuddham avartata
translated: Then a terrible battle of weapons ensued, great king,

analyzed: graha yuddham yathā ghoram prajā saṃharaṇe abhūt
translated: like the terrible battle of the planets that occurs at the destruction of beings.

original: te bāṇāḥ samasajjanta kṣiptās tābhyāṃ tu bhārata
analyzed: te bāṇāḥ samasajjanta kṣiptāḥ tābhyām tu bhārata
translated: Those arrows shot by them, O Bharata,

original: dyotayanto diśaḥ sarvās tac ca sainyaṃ samantataḥ
analyzed: dyotayantaḥ diśaḥ sarvāḥ tat ca sainyam samantataḥ
translated: illuminated all the directions and that army all around.

analyzed: bāṇa saṃgha āvṛtam ghoram ākāśam samapadyata
translated: The sky became covered with a terrible net of arrows,

analyzed: uklā pāta kṛtam yadvat prajānām saṃkṣaye nṛpa
translated: like the one created by the fall of meteors at the destruction of beings, O king.

analyzed: bāṇa abhighātāt saṃjajñe tatra bhārata pāvakaḥ
translated: And from the impact of the arrows, a fire arose there, O Bharata,
with sparks and blazing flames, which consumed both armies.

analyzed: tatra siddhāḥ mahā rāja saṃpatantaḥ bruvan vacaḥ
translated: There, the Siddhas, O great king, flying about, spoke these words:

original: ati yuddhāni sarvāṇi yuddham etat tato 'dhikam
analyzed: ati yuddhāni sarvāṇi yuddham etat tatas dhikam
translated: This battle surpasses all other battles.

analyzed: sarva yuddhāni ca etasya kalām na arhanti ṣoḍaśīm
translated: All other battles are not worth even a sixteenth part of this.

original: naitādṛśaṃ punar yuddhaṃ na bhūtaṃ na bhaviṣyati
analyzed: na etādṛśam punar yuddham na bhūtam na bhaviṣyati
translated: Such a battle has never been before, nor will there ever be one again.

original: aho jñānena saṃyuktāv ubhau cograparākramau🔽aho śauryeṇa saṃpannāv ubhau brāhmaṇapāṇḍavau
analyzed: aho jñānena saṃyuktau ubhau ca ugra parākramau  aho śauryeṇa saṃpannau ubhau brāhmaṇa pāṇḍavau
translated: Oh, both of them are endowed with knowledge and fierce valor!🔽Oh, both the Brahmana and Pandava are endowed with courage!

original: aho bhīme balaṃ bhīmam etayoś ca kṛtāstratā
analyzed: aho bhīme balam bhīmam etayoḥ ca kṛtāstra tā
translated: Oh, the terrible strength of Bhima and the skill in weapons of these two!

original: aho vīryasya sāratvam aho sauṣṭhavam etayoḥ
analyzed: aho vīryasya sāra tvam aho sauṣṭhavam etayoḥ
translated: Oh, the essence of valor and the excellence of these two!

analyzed: sthitau etau hi samare kāla antaka yama upamau
translated: These two stand in battle like Death and the Destroyer at the end of time,

original: rudrau dvāv iva saṃbhūtau yathā dvāv iva bhāskarau
analyzed: rudrau dvau iva saṃbhūtau yathā dvau iva bhāskarau
translated: like two Rudras come together, like two suns,

original: yamau vā puruṣavyāghrau ghorarūpāv imau raṇe
analyzed: yamau vā puruṣa vyāghrau ghora rūpau imau raṇe
translated: like the twins, those tigers among men, terrible in form in battle,

original: śrūyante sma tadā vācaḥ siddhānāṃ vai muhur muhuḥ
analyzed: śrūyante sma tadā vācaḥ siddhānām vai muhur muhur
translated: the sounds of the Siddhas were heard again and again, saying:

analyzed: siṃhanādaḥ ca saṃjajñe sametānām divaukasām
translated: There was a lion's roar among the assembled gods,

original: adbhutaṃ cāpy acintyaṃ ca dṛṣṭvā karma tayor mṛdhe
analyzed: adbhutam ca api acintyam ca dṛṣṭvā karma tayoḥ mṛdhe
translated: having seen that wonderful and inconceivable feat in battle of those two,

analyzed: siddha cāraṇa saṃghānām vismayaḥ samapadyata
translated: there was amazement among the hosts of Siddhas and Charanas.

original: praśaṃsanti tadā devāḥ siddhāś ca paramarṣayaḥ
analyzed: praśaṃsanti tadā devāḥ siddhāḥ ca parama ṛṣayaḥ
translated: The gods, the Siddhas and the great sages praised them then,

original: sādhu drauṇe mahābāho sādhu bhīmeti cābruvan🔽tau śūrau samare rājan parasparakṛtāgasau
analyzed: sādhu drauṇe mahā bāho sādhu bhīma iti ca abruvan  tau śūrau samare rājan paraspara kṛta āgasau
translated: saying 'Well done, O son of Drona! Well done, O mighty-armed one! Well done, O Bhima!'🔽Those two heroes, O king, in that battle, each offended against the other,

analyzed: parasparam udaikṣetām krodhāt udvṛtya cakṣuṣī
translated: stared at each other with eyes rolling in rage.

analyzed: krodha rakta īkṣaṇau tau tu krodhāt prasphurita adharau
translated: Their eyes red with rage, their lips trembling with anger,

analyzed: krodhāt saṃdaṣṭa daśanau saṃdaṣṭa daśanacchadau
translated: Their teeth clenched in rage, their lips biting their teeth,

analyzed: anyonyam chādayantau sma śara vṛṣṭyā mahā rathau
translated: Those two great warriors covered each other with showers of arrows,

analyzed: śara ambu dhārau samare śastra vidyut prakāśinau
translated: Like clouds raining water in the battle, lightning flashing with weapons,

original: tāv anyonyaṃ dhvajau viddhvā sārathī ca mahārathau
analyzed: tau anyonyam dhvajau viddhvā sārathī ca mahā rathau
translated: Having pierced each other's flags and charioteers, those two great warriors,

analyzed: anyonyasya hayān viddhvā bibhidāte parasparam
translated: Having pierced each other's horses, struck each other.

original: tataḥ kruddhau mahārāja bāṇau gṛhya mahāhave
analyzed: tatas kruddhau mahā rāja bāṇau gṛhya mahā āhave
translated: Then, O great king, those two, filled with rage, took up arrows in that great battle,

analyzed: ubhau cikṣipatuḥ tūrṇam anyonyasya vadha eṣiṇau
translated: And quickly hurled them at each other, each desiring to kill the other.

original: tau sāyakau mahārāja dyotamānau camūmukhe🔽ājaghnāte samāsādya vajravegau durāsadau
analyzed: tau sāyakau mahā rāja dyotamānau camū mukhe  ājaghnāte samāsādya vajra vegau durāsadau
translated: Those two arrows, O great king, shining at the head of the army,🔽Struck each other, being irresistible like the speed of thunder.

original: tau parasparavegāc ca śarābhyāṃ ca bhṛśāhatau
analyzed: tau paraspara vegāt ca śarābhyām ca bhṛśa āhatau
translated: Struck severely by each other's force and by the arrows,

analyzed: nipetatuḥ mahā vīrau sva rathopasthayoḥ tadā
translated: Those two great heroes fell down on the seats of their chariots.

original: tatas tu sārathir jñātvā droṇaputram acetanam
analyzed: tatas tu sārathiḥ jñātvā droṇaputram acetanam
translated: Then the charioteer, knowing that the son of Drona was unconscious,

analyzed: apovāha raṇāt rājan sarva kṣatrasya paśyataḥ
translated: Took him away from the battle, O king, while all the kshatriyas looked on.

original: tathaiva pāṇḍavaṃ rājan vihvalantaṃ muhur muhuḥ
analyzed: tathā eva pāṇḍavam rājan vihvalantam muhur muhur
translated: In the same way, O king, the Pandava, reeling again and again,

analyzed: apovāha rathena ājau sārathiḥ śatru tāpanam
translated: His charioteer then carried away on his chariot that scorcher of enemies.

original: saṃjaya uvāca🔽śrutakīrtim athāyāntaṃ kirantaṃ niśitāñ śarān🔽madrarājo mahārāja vārayām āsa hṛṣṭavat
analyzed: saṃjayaḥ uvāca  śrutakīrtim atha āyāntam kirantam niśitām śarān  madra rājaḥ mahā rāja vārayām āsa hṛṣṭa vat
translated: Sanjaya said:🔽Then the king of Madra, O great king, cheerfully repulsed Shrutakirti, who was advancing, scattering sharp arrows.

original: madrarājaṃ samāsādya śrutakīrtir mahārathaḥ🔽vivyādha bhallais triṃśatyā kārtasvaravibhūṣitaiḥ
analyzed: madra rājam samāsādya śrutakīrtiḥ mahā rathaḥ  vivyādha bhallaiḥ triṃśatyā kārtasvara vibhūṣitaiḥ
translated: Having approached the king of Madra, the great warrior Shrutakirti🔽pierced him with thirty broad arrows adorned with gold.

original: prativivyādha taṃ śalyas tribhis tūrṇam ajihmagaiḥ🔽sārathiṃ cāsya bhallena bhṛśaṃ vivyādha bhārata
analyzed: prativivyādha tam śalyaḥ tribhiḥ tūrṇam ajihmagaiḥ  sārathim ca asya bhallena bhṛśam vivyādha bhārata
translated: Shalya quickly pierced him in return with three straight-flying arrows,🔽and with another broad arrow, O Bharata, he severely wounded his charioteer.

original: sa śalyaṃ śaravarṣeṇa chādayām āsa saṃyuge
analyzed: sa śalyam śara varṣeṇa chādayām āsa saṃyuge
translated: He then covered Shalya with a shower of arrows in the battle

analyzed: mumoca niśitān bāṇān madra rāja ratham prati
translated: and released sharp arrows towards the chariot of the king of Madra.

analyzed: tatas śalyaḥ mahā rāja śruta kīrti bhuja cyutān
translated: Then Shalya, O great king, in that battle, with his own straight-tufted arrows

analyzed: ciccheda samare bāṇān bāṇaiḥ saṃnata parvabhiḥ
translated: cut down the arrows released from the arms of Shrutakirti.

original: śrutakīrtis tataḥ śalyaṃ bhittvā navabhir āyasaiḥ
analyzed: śrutakīrtiḥ tatas śalyam bhittvā navabhiḥ āyasaiḥ
translated: Shrutakirti then, having pierced Shalya with nine iron arrows,

original: sārathiṃ tribhir ānarchat punaḥ śalyaṃ ca pañcabhiḥ
analyzed: sārathim tribhiḥ ānarchat punar śalyam ca pañcabhiḥ
translated: again wounded his charioteer with three and Shalya himself with five.

original: tasya śalyo dhanuś chittvā hastāvāpaṃ nikṛtya ca
analyzed: tasya śalyaḥ dhanuḥ chittvā hasta āvāpam nikṛtya ca
translated: Shalya, having cut down his bow and severed his arm-guard,

original: vivyādha samare tūrṇaṃ saptabhis taṃ śarottamaiḥ🔽athānyad dhanur ādāya śrutakīrtir mahārathaḥ
analyzed: vivyādha samare tūrṇam saptabhiḥ tam śara uttamaiḥ  atha anyat dhanuḥ ādāya śrutakīrtiḥ mahā rathaḥ
translated: Quickly pierced him in that battle with seven excellent arrows.🔽Then the great warrior Shrutkirti, taking up another bow,

analyzed: madra īśvaram catuḥṣaṣṭyā bāhvoḥ urasi ca arpayat
translated: Struck the lord of the Madras with sixty-four arrows in the arms and chest.

original: tatas tu samare rājaṃs tena viddhaḥ śilīmukhaiḥ
analyzed: tatas tu samare rājan tena viddhaḥ śilīmukhaiḥ
translated: Then in that battle, O king, having been pierced with those arrows,

original: prativivyādha taṃ cāpi navatyā niśitaiḥ śaraiḥ
analyzed: prativivyādha tam ca api navatyā niśitaiḥ śaraiḥ
translated: He pierced him in return with ninety sharp arrows.

original: tasya madreśvaraś cāpaṃ punaś ciccheda māriṣa🔽saṃchinnadhanvā samare gadāṃ cikṣepa satvaraḥ
analyzed: tasya madra īśvaraḥ cāpam punar ciccheda māriṣa  saṃchinna dhanvā samare gadām cikṣepa sa tvaraḥ
translated: The lord of the Madras then again cut off his bow, O venerable one.🔽With his bow cut off in the battle, he quickly hurled a mace,

original: paṭṭair jāmbūnadair baddhāṃ rūpyapaṭṭaiś ca bhārata
analyzed: paṭṭaiḥ jāmbūnadaiḥ baddhām rūpya paṭṭaiḥ ca bhārata
translated: Bound with strips of gold and silver cloth, O descendant of Bharata,

analyzed: bhrājamānām yathā nārīm divya vastra vibhūṣitām
translated: Shining like a woman adorned with divine garments and ornaments.

analyzed: tām āpatantīm sahasā dīpyamāna aśani prabhām
translated: As it suddenly descended, blazing like lightning,

original: śarair anekasāhasrair vyaṣṭambhayata madrarāṭ🔽viṣṭabhya ca gadāṃ vīraḥ pātayitvā ca bhūtale
analyzed: śaraiḥ aneka sāhasraiḥ vyaṣṭambhayata madra rāj  viṣṭabhya ca gadām vīraḥ pātayitvā ca bhū tale
translated: The king of the Madras immobilized it with many thousands of arrows.🔽Having immobilized the mace and brought it down to the ground,

analyzed: śrutakīrtim atha āyattaḥ rājan vivyādha pañcabhiḥ
translated: The hero then, O king, focused on Shrutkirti and pierced him with five arrows.

original: tasya śaktiṃ raṇe bhūyaś cikṣepa bhujagopamām
analyzed: tasya śaktim raṇe bhūyas cikṣepa bhujaga upamām
translated: Again he hurled a spear in the battle, resembling a serpent,

original: tāṃ dvidhā cācchinac chalyo medinyāṃ sā tv aśīryata
analyzed: tām dvidhā ca ācchinat śalyaḥ medinyām sā tu aśīryata
translated: Shalya cut it in two and it fell to the ground.

original: tasya śalyaḥ kṣurapreṇa yantuḥ kāyāc chiro 'harat
analyzed: tasya śalyaḥ kṣurapreṇa yantuḥ kāyāt śiraḥ harat
translated: With a kshurapra arrow, Shalya then severed the head of his charioteer from his body.

original: bālahastād yathā śyena āmiṣaṃ vai narottama
analyzed: bāla hastāt yathā śyenaḥ āmiṣam vai narottama
translated: O best of men, it was like a hawk snatching away a piece of meat from the hand of a child.

original: sa papāta rathopasthāt sārathis tasya bhārata
analyzed: sa papāta rathopasthāt sārathiḥ tasya bhārata
translated: The charioteer fell down from the chariot platform, O descendant of Bharata.

original: tatas te prādravan saṃkhye hayās tasya mahātmanaḥ
analyzed: tatas te prādravan saṃkhye hayāḥ tasya mahātmanaḥ
translated: Then the horses of that great being ran away in the battle.

analyzed: palāyamānaiḥ taiḥ aśvaiḥ saḥ upanītaḥ raṇa ajirāt
translated: He was carried away from the battlefield by those fleeing horses.

original: śrutakīrtir mahārāja paśyatāṃ sarvayodhinām🔽tato madreśvaro rājā pāṇḍavānām anīkinīm
analyzed: śruta kīrtiḥ mahā rāja paśyatām sarva yodhinām  tatas madra īśvaraḥ rājā pāṇḍavānām anīkinīm
translated: O great king, while all the warriors were watching, Shrutakirti🔽Then the king of the Madras, filled with joy,🔽plunged into the army of the Pandavas

original: vyagāhata mudā yukto nalinīṃ dvirado yathā
analyzed: vyagāhata mudā yuktaḥ nalinīm dviradaḥ yathā
translated: like an elephant into a lotus pond.

original: lolayām āsa sa balaṃ siṃhaḥ paśugaṇān iva
analyzed: lolayām āsa sa balam siṃhaḥ paśu gaṇān iva
translated: He agitated that army like a lion agitating a herd of deer.

analyzed: śalyaḥ tatra mahā raṅge pāṇḍavānām mahātmanām
translated: In that great arena, Shalya

analyzed: nihatya pāṇḍu pāñcālān pṛtanāsu vyavasthitaḥ
translated: having killed the Pandus and Panchalas, stood in the midst of the battlefield.

original: aśobhata raṇe śalyo vidhūmo 'gnir iva jvalan🔽senākakṣaṃ mahad dagdhvā kakṣam agnir ivotthitaḥ
analyzed: aśobhata raṇe śalyaḥ vidhūmaḥ gniḥ iva jvalan  senā kakṣam mahat dagdhvā kakṣam agniḥ iva utthitaḥ
translated: Shalya shone in the battle like a smokeless flaming fire.🔽Having burnt a great mass of troops, he stood like a fire that has arisen.

original: sthito rarāja samare puraṃ dagdhveva śaṃkaraḥ
analyzed: sthitaḥ rarāja samare puram dagdhvā iva śaṃkaraḥ
translated: Standing in the battle, he shone like Shankara after burning a city.

analyzed: dhṛtarāṣṭraḥ uvāca
translated: Dhritarashtra said:

analyzed: yathā saṃśaptakaiḥ sārdham arjunasya abhavat raṇaḥ
translated: How did the battle between Arjuna and the oath-bound warriors take place?

analyzed: sūtaputrasya pāñcālaiḥ katham yuddham pravartitam
translated: And how did the battle between the Suta's son and the Panchalas commence?

original: aśvatthāmnas tu yad yuddham arjunasya ca saṃjaya
analyzed: aśvatthāmnaḥ tu yat yuddham arjunasya ca saṃjaya
translated: And, O Sanjaya, what was the battle between Ashvatthama and Arjuna?

original: anyeṣāṃ ca madīyānāṃ pāṇḍavais tad bravīhi me
analyzed: anyeṣām ca madīyānām pāṇḍavaiḥ tat bravīhi me
translated: And between others of my side and the Pandavas? Tell me that.

analyzed: saṃjayaḥ uvāca
translated: Sanjaya said:

original: śṛṇu rājan yathāvṛttaṃ saṃgrāmaṃ bruvato mama
analyzed: śṛṇu rājan yathāvṛttam saṃgrāmam bruvataḥ mama
translated: Listen, O king, as I describe the battle that took place,

original: vīrāṇāṃ śatrubhiḥ sārdhaṃ dehapāpmapraṇāśanam🔽pārthaḥ saṃśaptakagaṇaṃ praviśyārṇavasaṃnibham🔽vyakṣobhayad amitraghno mahāvāta ivārṇavam
analyzed: vīrāṇām śatrubhiḥ sārdham deha pāpma praṇāśanam  pārthaḥ saṃśaptaka gaṇam praviśya arṇava saṃnibham  vyakṣobhayat amitra ghnaḥ mahā vātaḥ iva arṇavam
translated: As it happened, between the heroes and their enemies, destroying their bodies and lives.🔽Partha, the slayer of enemies, having entered the army of the oath-bound warriors, resembling an ocean,🔽Agitated them, like a great wind agitates the ocean.

original: śirāṃsy unmathya vīrāṇāṃ śitair bhallair dhanaṃjayaḥ
analyzed: śirāṃsi unmathya vīrāṇām śitaiḥ bhallaiḥ dhanaṃjayaḥ
translated: Having severed the heads of the heroes with sharp broad-headed arrows,

analyzed: pūrṇa candra ābha vaktrāṇi su akṣi bhrū daśanāni ca
translated: With faces like the full moon, with beautiful eyes, eyebrows and teeth,

original: saṃtastāra kṣitiṃ kṣipraṃ vinālair nalinair iva
analyzed: saṃtastāra kṣitim kṣipram vinālaiḥ nalinaiḥ iva
translated: He quickly covered the earth with them, as if with lotuses without stalks.

analyzed: su vṛttān āyatān puṣṭān candana aguru bhūṣitān
translated: Well-rounded, long, and well-nourished arms, adorned with sandalwood and aloe,

analyzed: sa āyudhān sa tanutrāṇān pañcāsya uraga saṃnibhān
translated: With weapons and armor, resembling five-hooded serpents,

analyzed: bāhūn kṣuraiḥ amitrāṇām vicakarta arjunaḥ raṇe
translated: Arjuna cut off in battle with razors the arms of his enemies.

original: dhuryān dhuryatarān sūtān dhvajāṃś cāpāni sāyakān
analyzed: dhuryān dhuryatarān sūtān dhvajān cāpāni sāyakān
translated: The best, the excellent charioteers, the flags and bows and arrows,

original: pāṇīn aratnīn asakṛd bhallaiś ciccheda pāṇḍavaḥ
analyzed: pāṇīn aratnīn asakṛt bhallaiḥ ciccheda pāṇḍavaḥ
translated: The hands and forearms, the Pandava repeatedly cut off with broad-headed arrows.

original: dvipān hayān rathāṃś caiva sārohān arjuno raṇe🔽śarair anekasāhasrai rājan ninye yamakṣayam
analyzed: dvipān hayān rathān ca eva sa ārohān arjunaḥ raṇe  śaraiḥ aneka sāhasraiḥ rājan ninye yama kṣayam
translated: Elephants, horses and chariots with riders, Arjuna in battle,🔽With many thousands of arrows, O king, led to Yama's abode.

original: taṃ pravīraṃ pratīyātā nardamānā ivarṣabhāḥ🔽vāśitārtham abhikruddhā huṃkṛtvā cābhidudruvuḥ
analyzed: tam pravīram nardamānāḥ iva ṛṣabhāḥ  vāśitā artham abhikruddhāḥ huṃkṛtvā ca abhidudruvuḥ
translated: As if roaring bulls, they rushed towards that hero,🔽As if in anger for the sake of a cow, they neighed and charged.

original: nighnantam abhijaghnus te śaraiḥ śṛṅgair ivarṣabhāḥ
analyzed: nighnantam abhijaghnuḥ te śaraiḥ śṛṅgaiḥ iva ṛṣabhāḥ
translated: They struck him as he struck them, with arrows like bulls with horns.

original: tasya teṣāṃ ca tad yuddham abhaval lomaharṣaṇam🔽trailokyavijaye yādṛg daityānāṃ saha vajriṇā
analyzed: tasya teṣām ca tat yuddham abhavan loma harṣaṇam  trailokya vijaye yādṛś daityānām saha vajriṇā
translated: That battle between him and them was hair-raising,🔽Like that between the gods and demons in the conquest of the three worlds.

analyzed: kṛtaḥ daśa aṃśaḥ kuśalena yudhyatā
translated: The skillful one fought, making ten parts,

original: yathā havis tad daśadaivataṃ tathā🔽sa pādaśo rākṣasabhojanān bahūn🔽pradāya pāṇḍyo 'śvamanuṣyakuñjarān
analyzed: yathā haviḥ tat daśa daivatam tathā  sa pādaśas rākṣasa bhojanān bahūn  pradāya pāṇḍyo śva manuṣya kuñjarān

analyzed: tatas praśāntaḥ salila pravāhataḥ  samāpta vidyam tu guroḥ sutam nṛpaḥ  samāpta karmāṇam upetya te sutaḥ

analyzed: suhṛd vṛtaḥ utyartham apūjayat mudā

analyzed: jite balau viṣṇum iva amara īśvaraḥ

analyzed: dhṛtarāṣṭraḥ uvāca
translated: Dhritarashtra said:

translated: Sanjaya said:

original: aśvatthāmnaś ca saṃkalpād dhatāḥ karṇena sṛñjayāḥ

analyzed: iti ācaṣṭa su durdharṣaḥ vāsudevaḥ kirīṭine

original: etac chrutvā ca dṛṣṭvā ca bhrātur ghoraṃ mahad bhayam

analyzed: bhīmasena mukhāḥ pārthāḥ sūtaputra mukhāḥ vayam

analyzed: tatas pravavṛte bhūyas saṃgrāmaḥ rāja sattama
translated: Then again the battle commenced, O best of kings,

analyzed: karṇasya pāṇḍavānām ca yama rāṣṭra vivardhanaḥ
translated: Between Karna and the Pandavas, increasing the kingdom of Yama.

original: dhanūṃṣi bāṇān parighān asitomarapaṭṭiśān🔽musalāni bhuśuṇḍīś ca śaktiṛṣṭiparaśvadhān

analyzed: bāṇa jyā tala śabdena dyām diśaḥ pradiśaḥ viyat

analyzed: jyā talatra dhanuḥ śabdāḥ kuñjarāṇām ca bṛṃhitam

original: tāḍitānāṃ ca patatāṃ ninādaḥ sumahān abhūt
analyzed: tāḍitānām ca patatām ninādaḥ su mahān abhūt

analyzed: teṣām nānadyatām ca eva śastra vṛṣṭim ca muñcatām

analyzed: tatas karṇaḥ dviṣat senām śara varṣaiḥ viloḍayan
translated: Then Karna, agitating the enemy army with showers of arrows,

analyzed: varma deha asu mathanaiḥ dhanuṣaḥ pracyutaiḥ śaraiḥ

translated: Sanjaya said:

analyzed: hastibhiḥ tu mahāmātrāḥ tava putreṇa coditāḥ

analyzed: prācyāḥ ca dākṣiṇātyāḥ ca pravīrāḥ gaja yodhinaḥ

analyzed: mekalāḥ kośalāḥ madrāḥ daśārṇāḥ niṣadhāḥ tathā
translated: The Mekalas, Koshalas, Madras, Dasharnas, and Nishadas,

analyzed: gaja yuddheṣu kuśalāḥ kaliṅgaiḥ saha bhārata
translated: Skilled in elephant warfare, along with the Kalingas, O Bharata,

analyzed: śara tomara nārācaiḥ vṛṣṭimantaḥ iva ambudāḥ
translated: Like rain-bearing clouds with arrows, spears, and iron arrows,

original: siṣicus te tataḥ sarve pāñcālācalam āhave🔽tān saṃmimardiṣur nāgān pārṣṇyaṅguṣṭhāṅkuśair bhṛśam
analyzed: siṣicuḥ te tatas sarve pāñcāla acalam āhave  tān nāgān pārṣṇi aṅguṣṭha aṅkuśaiḥ bhṛśam

analyzed: dviradān abhivivyādha kṣiptaiḥ giri nibhām śaraiḥ
translated: He pierced those elephant-like mountains with hurled arrows.

analyzed: pracchādyamānaḥ dviradaiḥ meghaiḥ iva divākaraḥ

translated: They were like snakes whose fangs had been broken, whose poison had been destroyed, and who had been trodden upon with the feet.

original: tān abravīt tataḥ karṇaḥ kruddhaḥ sarpa iva śvasan
analyzed: tān abravīt tatas karṇaḥ kruddhaḥ sarpaḥ iva śvasan
translated: Then Karna, angry and breathing like a snake,

analyzed: karam kareṇa abhipīḍya prekṣamāṇaḥ tava ātmajam
translated: squeezing his hands together and looking at your son,

original: yatto dṛḍhaś ca dakṣaś ca dhṛtimān arjunaḥ sadā
analyzed: yattaḥ dṛḍhaḥ ca dakṣaḥ ca dhṛtimān arjunaḥ sadā
translated: said: Arjuna is always careful, firm, skillful, and resolute.

original: sa bodhayati cāpy enaṃ prāptakālam adhokṣajaḥ
analyzed: sa bodhayati ca api enam prāpta kālam adhokṣajaḥ
translated: And at the right time, Adhokshaja (Krishna) awakens him.

analyzed: sahasā astra visargeṇa vayam tena adya vañcitāḥ
translated: Today we have been deceived by him through the discharge of a thousand weapons.

original: śvas tv ahaṃ tasya saṃkalpaṃ sarvaṃ hantā mahīpate
analyzed: śvas tu aham tasya saṃkalpam sarvam hantā mahīpate
translated: But tomorrow, O lord of the earth, I will destroy all his plans.

original: evam uktas tathety uktvā so 'nujajñe nṛpottamān
analyzed: evam uktaḥ tathā iti uktvā saḥ nujajñe nṛpa uttamān
translated: Thus addressed, they said, So be it, and the king dismissed those best of kings.

original: te 'nujñātā nṛpāḥ sarve svāni veśmāni bhejire
analyzed: te nujñātāḥ nṛpāḥ sarve svāni veśmāni bhejire
translated: All those kings, thus dismissed, went to their own houses.

original: sukhoṣitās te rajanīṃ hṛṣṭā yuddhāya niryayuḥ
analyzed: sukha uṣitāḥ te rajanīm hṛṣṭāḥ yuddhāya niryayuḥ
translated: Having happily spent the night, they joyfully set out for battle.

analyzed: te paśyan vihitam vyūham dharmarājena durjayam
translated: They saw the invincible array formed by Dharmaraja.

original: prayatnāt kurumukhyena bṛhaspatyuśanomatāt🔽atha pratīpakartāraṃ satataṃ vijitātmanām
analyzed: prayatnāt kuru mukhyena bṛhaspati uśanaḥ matāt  atha pratīpa kartāram satatam vijita ātmanām
translated: With great effort, by the advice of Brihaspati and Ushanas, by the chief of the Kurus.

analyzed: sasmāra vṛṣabha skandham karṇam duryodhanaḥ tadā
translated: Then Duryodhana remembered Karna, whose shoulders were like those of a bull, the one who always thwarted the victorious,

analyzed: puraṃdara samam yuddhe marut gaṇa samam bale
translated: in battle equal to Purandara, in strength equal to the Marut troop,

analyzed: kārtavīrya samam vīrye karṇam rājñaḥ gamat manaḥ
translated: in valor equal to Kartavirya, Karna, the king's mind went to him.

original: sarveṣāṃ caiva sainyānāṃ karṇam evāgaman manaḥ
analyzed: sarveṣām ca eva sainyānām karṇam eva agamat manaḥ
translated: And the minds of all the soldiers went to Karna,

analyzed: sūtaputram mahā iṣvāsam bandhum ātyayikeṣu iva
translated: to the great archer, the son of a suta, like a relative in times of calamity.

analyzed: dhṛtarāṣṭraḥ uvāca
translated: Dhritarashtra said:

original: yad vo 'gaman mano mandāḥ karṇaṃ vaikartanaṃ tadā
analyzed: yat vaḥ gamat manaḥ mandāḥ karṇam vaikartanam tadā
translated: When your minds went to Karna Vaikartana, you foolish ones,

original: apy adrākṣata taṃ yūyaṃ śītārtā iva bhāskaram
analyzed: api adrākṣata tam yūyam śīta ārtāḥ iva bhāskaram
translated: did you see him, like those afflicted by cold seeing the sun?

original: kṛte 'vahāre sainyānāṃ pravṛtte ca raṇe punaḥ
analyzed: kṛte vahāre sainyānām pravṛtte ca raṇe punar
translated: When the withdrawal of the armies took place and the battle commenced again,

analyzed: katham vaikartanaḥ karṇaḥ tatra ayudhyata saṃjaya
translated: How did Vaikartana Karna fight there, O Sanjaya?

original: kathaṃ ca pāṇḍavāḥ sarve yuyudhus tatra sūtajam
analyzed: katham ca pāṇḍavāḥ sarve yuyudhuḥ tatra sūtajam
translated: And how did all the Pandavas fight against the son of a suta there?

original: karṇo hy eko mahābāhur hanyāt pārthān sasomakān
analyzed: karṇaḥ hi ekaḥ mahā bāhuḥ hanyāt pārthān sa somakān
translated: For Karna alone, the mighty-armed one, could have killed the Parthas along with the Somakas,

analyzed: karṇasya bhujayoḥ vīryam śakra viṣṇu samam matam
translated: The strength of Karna's arms is considered equal to that of Shakra and Vishnu,

analyzed: tathā astrāṇi su ghorāṇi vikramaḥ ca mahātmanaḥ
translated: And so are his terrible weapons and the valor of the great-souled one.

original: mama caiva sadā mandaḥ śaṃsate nityam agrataḥ
analyzed: mama ca eva sadā mandaḥ śaṃsate nityam agratas
translated: But that wretched one always praises him in front of me,

original: karṇaś ca tān maheṣvāsān pāṇḍuputrān mahārathān
analyzed: karṇaḥ ca tān mahā iṣvāsān pāṇḍu putrān mahā rathān
translated: And Karna, the great archer, against those great maharatha sons of Pandu,

analyzed: duryodhanam tadā dṛṣṭvā pāṇḍavena bhṛśa arditam
translated: Seeing Duryodhana then severely afflicted by the Pandava,

analyzed: parākrāntān pāṇḍu sutān dṛṣṭvā ca api mahā āhave
translated: And seeing the powerful sons of Pandu in the great battle,

original: karṇam āśritya saṃgrāme darpo duryodhane punaḥ
analyzed: karṇam āśritya saṃgrāme darpaḥ duryodhane punar
translated: Relying on Karna in the battle, Duryodhana's pride again

original: jetum utsahate pārthān saputrān sahakeśavān🔽aho bata mahad duḥkhaṃ yatra pāṇḍusutān raṇe
analyzed: jetum utsahate pārthān sa putrān saha keśavān  aho bata mahat duḥkham yatra pāṇḍu sutān raṇe
translated: Arises from the desire to conquer the Parthas along with their sons and Keshava.🔽Alas, what a great misfortune that in the battle the impetuous Karna

original: nātarad rabhasaḥ karṇo daivaṃ nūnaṃ parāyaṇam
analyzed: na atarat rabhasaḥ karṇaḥ daivam nūnam parāyaṇam
translated: Could not overcome the sons of Pandu! Destiny is surely supreme!

original: aho dyūtasya niṣṭheyaṃ ghorā saṃprati vartate
analyzed: aho dyūtasya niṣṭhā iyam ghorā saṃprati vartate
translated: Alas, this terrible culmination of the gambling match is now taking place,

analyzed: aho duḥkhāni tīvrāṇi duryodhana kṛtāni aham
translated: Oh, the terrible sorrows that I have suffered because of Duryodhana!🔽

analyzed: sahiṣyāmi su ghorāṇi śalya bhūtāni saṃjaya
translated: Alas! I will have to endure the extremely terrible and unbearable sufferings caused by Duryodhana, O Sanjaya, which are like thorns.

original: saubalaṃ ca tathā tāta nītimān iti manyate🔽karṇaś ca rabhaso nityaṃ rājānaṃ cāpy anuvrataḥ
analyzed: saubalam ca tathā tāta nītimān iti manyate  karṇaḥ ca rabhasaḥ nityam rājānam ca api anuvrataḥ
translated: And I consider Suvala's son to be wise, O son,🔽and Karna is always impetuous and devoted to the king.

original: karṇaṃ cāpratimaṃ yuddhe devair api durutsaham
analyzed: karṇam ca apratimam yuddhe devaiḥ api durutsaham
translated: And Karna, who is unmatched in battle and difficult to withstand even by the gods,

original: manyate 'bhyadhikaṃ pārthād daivaṃ cāsya hṛdi sthitam
analyzed: manyate bhyadhikam pārthāt daivam ca asya hṛdi sthitam
translated: he considers to be superior to Partha, and fate is in his heart.

analyzed: yuddheṣu nāma divyeṣu vartamāneṣu saṃjaya
translated: O Sanjaya, when those divine battles were going on,

original: aśrauṣaṃ nihatān putrān nityam eva ca nirjitān
analyzed: aśrauṣam nihatān putrān nityam eva ca nirjitān
translated: I always heard that my sons were killed and defeated.

original: na pāṇḍavānāṃ samare kaś cid asti nivārakaḥ
analyzed: na pāṇḍavānām samare kaḥ cit asti nivārakaḥ
translated: There is no one among the Pandavas who can resist them in battle,

original: strīmadhyam iva gāhanti daivaṃ hi balavattaram
analyzed: strī madhyam iva gāhanti daivam hi balavattaram
translated: they penetrate like a woman, for fate is more powerful.

analyzed: saṃjayaḥ uvāca
translated: Sanjaya said:

analyzed: rājan pūrva nimittāni dharmiṣṭhāni vicintaya
translated: O king, reflect on the most righteous omens of the past,

original: atikrāntaṃ hi yat kāryaṃ paścāc cintayatīti ca
analyzed: atikrāntam hi yat kāryam paścāt cintayati iti ca
translated: for what has been done in the past is thought of later,

original: tac cāsya na bhavet kāryaṃ cintayā ca vinaśyati
analyzed: tat ca asya na bhavet kāryam cintayā ca vinaśyati
translated: and that cannot be done again, and is destroyed by thought.

original: tad idaṃ tava kāryaṃ tu dūraprāptaṃ vijānatā
analyzed: tat idam tava kāryam tu dūra prāptam vijānatā
translated: But this task of yours has gone far away, known by the wise.

original: na kṛtaṃ yat tvayā pūrvaṃ prāptāprāptavicāraṇe
analyzed: na kṛtam yat tvayā pūrvam prāpta aprāpta vicāraṇe
translated: You did not do that earlier, when you were considering what to do and what not to do.

original: ukto 'si bahudhā rājan mā yudhyasveti pāṇḍavaiḥ
analyzed: uktaḥ u si bahudhā rājan mā yudhyasva iti pāṇḍavaiḥ
translated: O king! You were repeatedly told, 'Do not fight with the Pandavas.'

original: gṛhṇīṣe na ca tan mohāt pāṇḍaveṣu viśāṃ pate🔽tvayā pāpāni ghorāṇi samācīrṇāni pāṇḍuṣu
analyzed: gṛhṇīṣe na ca tat mohāt pāṇḍaveṣu viśām pate  tvayā pāpāni ghorāṇi samācīrṇāni pāṇḍuṣu
translated: But out of delusion, you did not accept it, O lord of the people, towards the Pandavas.🔽You have committed terrible sins against the sons of Pandu.

analyzed: tvad kṛte vartate ghoraḥ pārthivānām jana kṣayaḥ
translated: It is because of you that this terrible destruction of kings and people is taking place.

original: tat tv idānīm atikramya mā śuco bharatarṣabha
analyzed: tat tu idānīm atikramya mā śucaḥ bharata ṛṣabha
translated: But now that it has come to this, do not grieve, O bull among the Bharatas.

original: śṛṇu sarvaṃ yathāvṛttaṃ ghoraṃ vaiśasam acyuta
analyzed: śṛṇu sarvam yathāvṛttam ghoram vaiśasam acyuta
translated: Listen to everything as it happened, O undeteriorating one, this terrible carnage.

original: prabhātāyāṃ rajanyāṃ tu karṇo rājānam abhyayāt
analyzed: prabhātāyām rajanyām tu karṇaḥ rājānam abhyayāt
translated: When the night dawned, Karna approached the king.

analyzed: sametya ca mahā bāhuḥ duryodhanam abhāṣata
translated: Having approached, the mighty-armed one spoke to Duryodhana:

analyzed: adya rājan sameṣyāmi pāṇḍavena yaśasvinā
translated: Today, O king, I will engage with the illustrious Pandava.

original: haniṣyāmi ca taṃ vīraṃ sa vā māṃ nihaniṣyati
analyzed: haniṣyāmi ca tam vīram sa vā mām nihaniṣyati
translated: I will slay that hero, or he will slay me.

original: bahutvān mama kāryāṇāṃ tathā pārthasya pārthiva
analyzed: bahu tvāt mama kāryāṇām tathā pārthasya pārthiva
translated: O king, because of the multitude of my duties, and those of Partha,

original: nābhūt samāgamo rājan mama caivārjunasya ca
analyzed: na abhūt samāgamaḥ rājan mama ca eva arjunasya ca
translated: there was no meeting between me and Arjuna, O king.

original: idaṃ tu me yathāprajñaṃ śṛṇu vākyaṃ viśāṃ pate
analyzed: idam tu me yathāprajñam śṛṇu vākyam viśām pate
translated: But listen to these words of mine, O lord of the people, according to my wisdom.

original: anihatya raṇe pārthaṃ nāham eṣyāmi bhārata
analyzed: a nihatya raṇe pārtham na aham eṣyāmi bhārata
translated: Without slaying Partha in battle, I will not return, O Bharata.

original: hatapravīre sainye 'smin mayi caiva sthite yudhi
analyzed: hata pravīre sainye smin mayi ca eva sthite yudhi
translated: When the best warriors have been killed in this army and I am stationed in battle,

analyzed: abhiyāsyati mām pārthaḥ śakra śaktyā vinākṛtam
translated: Partha will attack me, deprived of the power of Shakra.

original: tataḥ śreyaskaraṃ yat te tan nibodha janeśvara
analyzed: tatas śreyaskaram yat te tat nibodha janeśvara
translated: Therefore, O lord of people, listen to what is best for you.

original: āyudhānāṃ ca yad vīryaṃ dravyāṇām arjunasya ca
analyzed: āyudhānām ca yat vīryam dravyāṇām arjunasya ca
translated: The strength of weapons, the power of Arjuna,

analyzed: kāyasya mahataḥ bhede lāghave dūra pātane
translated: The ability to penetrate a large body, quickness, long-distance shooting,

original: sauṣṭhave cāstrayoge ca savyasācī na matsamaḥ
analyzed: sauṣṭhave ca astra yoge ca savyasācī na mad samaḥ
translated: Skill and the combination of weapons - Savyasachi is not equal to me.

original: prāṇe śaurye ca vijñāne vikrame cāpi bhārata
analyzed: prāṇe śaurye ca vijñāne vikrame ca api bhārata
translated: In life force, courage, knowledge, valor and even in battle, O descendant of Bharata,

analyzed: nimitta jñāna yoge ca savyasācī na mad samaḥ
translated: In the ability to recognize signs, Savyasachi is not equal to me.

analyzed: sarva āyudha mahāmātram vijayam nāma tat dhanuḥ
translated: That bow named Vijaya, the best of all weapons,

analyzed: indra artham abhikāmena nirmitam viśvakarmaṇā
translated: was created by Vishvakarma for Indra.

original: yena daityagaṇān rājañ jitavān vai śatakratuḥ
analyzed: yena daitya gaṇān rājam jitavān vai śatakratuḥ
translated: With which Shatakratu, O king, conquered the hordes of demons,

original: yasya ghoṣeṇa daityānāṃ vimuhyanti diśo daśa
analyzed: yasya ghoṣeṇa daityānām vimuhyanti diśaḥ daśa
translated: By whose sound the demons are confused in the ten directions.

analyzed: tat bhārgavāya prāyacchat śakraḥ parama saṃmatam
translated: Shakra gave that extremely esteemed (bow) to Bhargava.

original: tad divyaṃ bhārgavo mahyam adadād dhanur uttamam
analyzed: tat divyam bhārgavaḥ mahyam adadāt dhanuḥ uttamam
translated: Bhargava gave that divine, excellent bow to me,

original: yena yotsye mahābāhum arjunaṃ jayatāṃ varam
analyzed: yena yotsye mahā bāhum arjunam jayatām varam
translated: With which I will fight the mighty-armed Arjuna, the best of the victorious.

original: yathendraḥ samare sarvān daiteyān vai samāgatān
analyzed: yathā indraḥ samare sarvān daiteyān vai samāgatān
translated: Just as Indra killed all the assembled daityas in battle,

original: nijaghāna tathā sarvāñ jeṣyāmi yudhi pāṇḍavān
analyzed: nijaghāna tathā sarvām jeṣyāmi yudhi pāṇḍavān
translated: so I will defeat all the Pandavas in battle.

original: dhanur ghoraṃ rāmadattaṃ gāṇḍīvāt tad viśiṣyate
analyzed: dhanuḥ ghoram rāma dattam gāṇḍīvāt tat viśiṣyate
translated: The terrible bow given by Rama is superior to Gandiva.

analyzed: tris sapta kṛtvas pṛthivī dhanuṣā tena nirjitā
translated: With that bow, the earth was conquered twenty-seven times.

original: dhanuṣo yasya karmāṇi divyāni prāha bhārgavaḥ
analyzed: dhanuṣaḥ yasya karmāṇi divyāni prāha bhārgavaḥ
translated: Bhargava spoke of the divine deeds of that bow.

original: tad rāmo hy adadān mahyaṃ yena yotsyāmi pāṇḍavam
analyzed: tat rāmaḥ hi adadāt mahyam yena yotsyāmi pāṇḍavam
translated: Rama gave it to me, with which I will fight the Pandava.

analyzed: adya duryodhana aham tvām nandayiṣye sa bāndhavam
translated: Today, O Duryodhana, I will delight you and your relatives

original: nihatya samare vīram arjunaṃ jayatāṃ varam
analyzed: nihatya samare vīram arjunam jayatām varam
translated: by killing in battle the hero Arjuna, the best of the victorious.

analyzed: sa parvata vana dvīpā hata dviṣ bhūḥ sa sāgarā
translated: The earth with its mountains, forests, islands and oceans, free from enemies,

analyzed: putra pautra pratiṣṭhā te bhaviṣyati adya pārthiva
translated: will be established today with your sons and grandsons, O king.

analyzed: na asādhyam vidyate me dya tvad priya artham viśeṣataḥ
translated: There is nothing unattainable for me today, especially for the sake of pleasing you,

analyzed: samyak dharma anuraktasya siddhiḥ ātmavataḥ yathā
translated: just as success is for one who is devoted to the true Dharma and has self-control.

original: na hi māṃ samare soḍhuṃ sa śakto 'gniṃ tarur yathā
analyzed: na hi mām samare soḍhum sa śaktaḥ gnim taruḥ yathā
translated: He is not able to withstand me in battle, like a tree cannot withstand fire.

original: avaśyaṃ tu mayā vācyaṃ yena hīno 'smi phalgunāt
analyzed: avaśyam tu mayā vācyam yena hīnaḥ smi phalgunāt
translated: But I must certainly speak of what I am inferior to Phalguna in.

original: jyā tasya dhanuṣo divyā tathākṣayyau maheṣudhī
analyzed: jyā tasya dhanuṣaḥ divyā tathā akṣayyau mahā iṣudhī
translated: His bowstring is divine, and he has two inexhaustible quivers of great arrows.

original: sārathis tasya govindo mama tādṛṅ na vidyate
analyzed: sārathiḥ tasya govindaḥ mama tādṛś na vidyate
translated: His charioteer is Govinda, and I do not have such a one.

original: tasya divyaṃ dhanuḥ śreṣṭhaṃ gāṇḍīvam ajaraṃ yudhi
analyzed: tasya divyam dhanuḥ śreṣṭham gāṇḍīvam ajaram yudhi
translated: His divine bow Gandiva is the best, undecaying in battle.

original: vijayaṃ ca mahad divyaṃ mamāpi dhanur uttamam
analyzed: vijayam ca mahat divyam mama api dhanuḥ uttamam
translated: And my great divine bow Vijaya is also the best.

original: tatrāham adhikaḥ pārthād dhanuṣā tena pārthiva
analyzed: tatra aham adhikaḥ pārthāt dhanuṣā tena pārthiva
translated: In that, O king, I am superior to Partha in terms of the bow.

original: mayā cābhyadhiko vīraḥ pāṇḍavas tan nibodha me
analyzed: mayā ca abhyadhikaḥ vīraḥ pāṇḍavaḥ tat nibodha me
translated: But the hero Pandava is superior to me, understand that from me.
And the Dasharha, the holder of the reins, is revered by all the worlds.

original: agnidattaś ca vai divyo rathaḥ kāñcanabhūṣaṇaḥ
analyzed: agnidattaḥ ca vai divyaḥ rathaḥ kāñcana bhūṣaṇaḥ
translated: And the divine chariot given by Agni is adorned with gold.

original: acchedyaḥ sarvato vīra vājinaś ca manojavāḥ
analyzed: acchedyaḥ sarvatas vīra vājinaḥ ca manaḥ javāḥ
translated: O hero, it is indestructible from all sides, and the horses have the speed of mind.

original: dhvajaś ca divyo dyutimān vānaro vismayaṃkaraḥ
analyzed: dhvajaḥ ca divyaḥ dyutimān vānaraḥ vismayaṃkaraḥ
translated: And the divine banner is radiant, the monkey is amazing.

original: kṛṣṇaś ca sraṣṭā jagato rathaṃ tam abhirakṣati
analyzed: kṛṣṇaḥ ca sraṣṭā jagataḥ ratham tam abhirakṣati
translated: And Krishna, the creator of the world, protects that chariot.

original: ebhir dravyair ahaṃ hīno yoddhum icchāmi pāṇḍavam
analyzed: ebhiḥ dravyaiḥ aham hīnaḥ yoddhum icchāmi pāṇḍavam
translated: With these things, I am inferior, yet I wish to fight with Pandava.

original: ayaṃ tu sadṛśo vīraḥ śalyaḥ samitiśobhanaḥ
analyzed: ayam tu sadṛśaḥ vīraḥ śalyaḥ samiti śobhanaḥ
translated: But this hero Shalya, the ornament of assemblies, is equal to me.

original: sārathyaṃ yadi me kuryād dhruvas te vijayo bhavet
analyzed: sārathyam yadi me kuryāt dhruvaḥ te vijayaḥ bhavet
translated: If he would act as my charioteer, then your victory would be certain.

original: tasya me sārathiḥ śalyo bhavatv asukaraḥ paraiḥ
analyzed: tasya me sārathiḥ śalyaḥ bhavatu asu karaḥ paraiḥ
translated: Let Shalya be my charioteer, invincible by the enemy.

original: nārācān gārdhrapatrāṃś ca śakaṭāni vahantu me
analyzed: nārācān gārdhra patrān ca śakaṭāni vahantu me
translated: Let my carts carry iron arrows with vulture feathers.

original: rathāś ca mukhyā rājendra yuktā vājibhir uttamaiḥ
analyzed: rathāḥ ca mukhyāḥ rāja indra yuktāḥ vājibhiḥ uttamaiḥ
translated: And let the best chariots, O lord of kings, yoked with excellent horses,

original: āyāntu paścāt satataṃ mām eva bharatarṣabha
analyzed: āyāntu paścāt satatam mām eva bharata ṛṣabha
